title: Dysregulated miR-124 mediates impaired social memory behavior caused by paternal early social isolation
affiliations: Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Neurodegeneration, Nanjing Medical University, Nanjing 211166, China
Center for Global Health, Nanjing Medical University, Nanjing 211166, China

background: Early social isolation (SI) in parents can negatively impact offspring behavior and neurodevelopment, but the mechanisms are unclear.
hypotheses: Paternal early SI causes social memory deficits and anxiety-like behavior in offspring.
Dysregulation of miR-124 mediates the intergenerational effects of early SI stress.
Altered miR-124/Nr4a1/glucocorticoid receptor expression in the mPFC contributes to impaired social behavior.
major_findings: Paternal early SI caused social memory deficits and anxiety-like behavior in F1 mice, exacerbated by additional SI in offspring.
Paternal SI led to reduced myelination and synaptic integrity in the mPFC of F1 mice, worsened by additional SI.
Elevated miR-124 levels in paternal sperm were epigenetically transmitted to offspring, altering miR-124/Nr4a1/glucocorticoid receptor expression in the mPFC.
Inhibiting miR-124 or overexpressing Nr4a1 in the mPFC of F1 mice improved social interaction and myelination.
Two-week SI exacerbated the downregulation of GR expression in the mPFC of F1 mice.
methods: Behavioral tests (three-chamber test, open-field test, elevated plus maze, Y-maze)
Quantitative reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR)
Primary cortical neuron and oligodendrocyte precursor cell cultures
